facts.text: Appeal is Civil Appeal No. 455/59 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 455/59.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated January 16, 1956 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Petition No. 448 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 16, 1956, of the former Nagpur High Court, in Misc. Petition No. 448 of 1954.

facts.text: Respondent was proprietor of mauza Bhivapur, Tehsil Umerer, District Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a proprietor of mauza Bhivapur, Tehsil Umerer, District Nagpur.

facts.text: Proprietary interest in the village abolished by Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950 (M.P. 1 of 1951).

anchor.surface_text: His proprietary interest in the village was abolished by the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950  M.P. 1 of 1951 .

facts.text: By s.4 of the Act, rights in pathways, village sites, hats, bazars, melas in Bhivapur vested in State of Madhya Pradesh free from encumbrances under s.4(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of s. 4 of the Act, ill rights, titles and interests, among others, in all pathways, village sites, hats, bazars and melas in Bhivapur vested in the State of Madhya Pradesh for the purposes of the State free from all encumbrances under s. 4 1  a  of the Act.

facts.text: Rights vested in State of Bombay by States Reorganisation Act, 1956, then to Maharashtra by Bombay Reorganisation Act, 1960 (11 of 1960).

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of the States Re-organisation Act, 1956 those rights vested in the State of Bombay and number by virtue of Bombay Re-Organisation Act, 1960  11 of 1960  in the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: Compensation proceedings for Bhivapur started in Revenue case No. 583/1-A-4/1950-51 before Compensation Officer, Umrer, decided on January 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: After the Act came into operation proceedings for companysensation in respect of the village Bhivapur were started in the companyrt of the Compensation Officer, Umrer, in Revenue case No. 583/1-A-4/1950-51 decided on January 19, 1952.

facts.text: Compensation Officer held 0.14 acres of Khasra No. 61/1 (recorded as abadi with bazar) settled with respondent under s.5(a).

anchor.surface_text: The Compensation Officer held that 0.14 acres of land out of Khasra No. 61/1 which is recorded in the village papers as abadi wherein a bazar is held, should be settled with the respondent under s. 5 a .

facts.text: Ottas and chabutras (with or without sheds) on bazar land belong to respondent. (common ground)

anchor.surface_text: On a portion of the land which was used for bazar, ottas and chabutras, with or without sheds, and separated by passages, exist. It is companymon ground that they belong to the respondent.

facts.text: Land covered by ottas and chabutras with sheds ordered settled with respondent. (common ground)

anchor.surface_text: It is also companymon ground that the land companyered by ottas and chabutras on which sheds have been companystructed were ordered to be settled on the respondent in the revenue case referred to above.

facts.text: Respondent claimed sheds, land under them, open uncovered ottas/chabutras and appurtenant land (total 2.85 acres) settled under s.5(a).

anchor.surface_text: The respondents companytention, however, was that number only the sheds and the land on which those sheds were erected but also the open uncovered ottas and chabutras should also have been settled with him by virtue of the provisions of s. 5 a  of the Act along with the land appurtenant to those structures. The total area of this land, according to him, is 2.85 acres.

facts.text: Appeal against Compensation Officer dismissed by Additional Commissioner on March 28, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, therefore, preferred an appeal against the order of the Compensation Officer which directed settling only 0.14 acres of land on him. That appeal was. however, dismissed by the Additional Commissioner of Land Reforms and Additional Commissioner of Settlement, Madhya Pradesh, on March 28, 1952.

facts.text: Respondent asked to remove ottas and chabutras.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter was asked to remove his ottas and chabutras.

facts.text: Press note issued May 16, 1952 by Directorate of Information and Publicity, Govt of MP: brick/stone ottas/chabutras to remain with ex-proprietors, land settled under s.5(a); mud ones vest in state.

anchor.surface_text: On May 16, 1952, a press numbere was issued by the Directorate of Information and Publicity, Government, of Madhya Pradesh the material portion of which runs thus The Government companysider that the option given to expropriators to remove the material etc., might cause hardship to them in such cases. Government have, therefore, decided on the following lines of action in such matters where the ottas and chabutras were, companystructed in brick and stone, they should be allowed to remain with the exproprietors and the land thereunder should be settled with them under section 5 a  of the Madhya Pradesh Abolition of Proprietary Rights Act, 1950  1 of 1951  on terms and companyditions determined by the Government and where the ottas and chabutras are in mud, the land Under them should be deemed to have vested in the State Government.

facts.text: Government issued instructions June 22, 1954 to Deputy Commissioners: give one month's notice to ex-proprietors to remove materials of ottas/chabutras except those with sheds.

anchor.surface_text: But after this press numbere was issued the Government, apparently on the advice of its law officers, issued instructions to the Deputy Commissioners on June 22, 1954, to give one months numberice all ex-proprietors to remove the materials, clear the site of ottas and chabutras other than those on which there were sheds.

facts.text: Notice issued to respondent on July 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of this, a numberice was issued to the respondent on July 13, 1954.

facts.text: Respondent filed petition under Art.226 before Nagpur High Court for writ to quash orders of Compensation Officer, appellate authority, Govt order June 22, 1954 and notice July 13, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Feeling aggrieved by this, the respondent preferred a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution before the High Court of Nagpur for issue of a writ of mandamus or certiorari or other appropriate to writ to quash the orders passed by the Commpensation Officer and the appellate authority as well as the order of the State Government of Madhya Pradesh dated June 22, 1954, and the numberice issued in pursuance thereto on July 13, 1954.

facts.text: High Court allowed petition, set aside impugned orders, directed State to settle entire Khasra No. 61/1 (12.85 acres) with respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the petition and set aside the impugned orders and directed the State Government to settle the on tire area of Khasra No. 61 /1 of Bhivapur with the respondent on such terms and companyditions as may be determined by it. It may be mentioned that the entire area of Khasra No. 61/1 is 12.85 acres or so.

facts.text: State sought certificate under Art.133(1)(c) from High Court, not granted.

anchor.surface_text: The State of Madhya Pradesh sought a certificate from the High Court under Art. 133 1  c  of the Constitution. But the certificate was number granted.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court on March 18, 1957 under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon a special leave petition was made before this Court under Art. 136 of the Constitution. Leave was granted by this Court by its order dated March 18, 1957.

facts.text: High Court held ottas and chabutras are buildings under s.5(a), land to be settled with ex-proprietor.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the High Court granted the petition of the respondent on the view that ottas and chabutras etc., are buildings within the meaning of s. 5 a  of the Act and that companysequently the State Government was bound to settle the land companyered by them with ex-proprietors along with land appurtenant to those structures.

facts.text: Respondent claims total market area 2.85 acres.

anchor.surface_text: For that the total market area as claimed by the number-applicant being only 2.85 the entire abadi area of 12.85 acres in Khasra No. 61/1 companyld number be granted and settled with the ex-proprietor.

facts.text: Khasra No. 61/1 entire area is 12.85 acres.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the entire area of Khasra No. 61/1 is 12.85 acres or so.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds uncovered ottas and chabutras are buildings under s.5(a), to be settled with land appurtenant.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was quite right in holding that even uncovered ottas and chabutras fall within the term building as used in s. 5 a  of the Act and, therefore, along with the land appurtenant to them they must be settled with the respondent.

facts.text: Counsel for respondent concedes only 2.85 acres needed, not entire 12.85.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bindra pointed out that the High Court was in error in asking the Government to settle the whole of Khasra No.61/1 on the respondent because whereas its area is 12.85 acres, the land companyered by the structures, including the appurtenant land, does number measure more than 2.85 acres. Mr. Purushottam Trikamdas, learned companynsel for the respondent readily companyceded this fact and said that the High Court has companymitted an error through an oversight and that all that the respondent wants is 2.85 acres of land and numberhing more.

facts.text: Supreme Court directs settlement of land covered by structures and appurtenant from Khasra 61/1, area to be determined by revenue authorities.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with him. It would be sufficient to direct the Government to settle with the respondent the whole of the land companyered by the structures as well as land appurtenant to those structures from out of Khasra No. 61/1. What the area of that land would be is a matter to be determined during the settlement proceedings.

holdings.text: Even uncovered ottas and chabutras fall within the term 'building' as used in s.5(a) of the Act and, therefore, along with the land appurtenant to them they must be settled with the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was quite right in holding that even uncovered ottas and chabutras fall within the term building as used in s. 5 a  of the Act and, therefore, along with the land appurtenant to them they must be settled with the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal meaning applies as 'something which is built'; ex-proprietor constructed within village site; precedents distinguished as context-specific to other statutes.

holdings.text: Section 5(a) is an exception to s.4(1)(a); reading together, buildings of proprietor on abadi land (including bazar portion) and appurtenant land must be settled with ex-proprietor.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 a  is an exception to s. 4 1  a  of the Act. No doubt, s. 4 1  a  provides for the vesting in the State of the land on which bazar is held. But reading that section along with s. 5 a  it is clear that where any buildings belonging to the proprietor exist on any portion of the abadi land that land, together with the land appurtenant to those buildings, bad to be settled with the ex-proprietor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction reconciles vesting under s.4(1)(a) with exception for proprietor's buildings under s.5(a).

holdings.text: Land on which bazar is held is part of village abadi land, so buildings thereon fall within s.5(a) and must be settled with ex-proprietor.

anchor.surface_text: Land on which the bazar is held is part of the village abadi land and, therefore, all buildings standing on such land would fall within s. 5 a  of the Act and would have to be settled with the ex-proprietor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Village site defined as abadi; bazar located within abadi.

holdings.text: The word 'buildings' is to be given its literal meaning as something which is built.

anchor.surface_text: The word buildings should, therefore, be given its literal meaning as something which is built.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Act protects ex-proprietor's investments in constructions within village site limits.

holdings.text: Question whether ottas and chabutras fall within term 'buildings' is not purely one of law; State not entitled to withdraw its concession.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the question whether ottas and chabutras fall within the term buildings is number purely one of law and the State is number entitled to withdraw that companycession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Involves statutory interpretation applied to specific structures and facts.

holdings.text: High Court erred in directing settlement of entire Khasra No.61/1 (12.85 acres); only land covered by structures plus appurtenant land to be settled.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bindra pointed out that the High Court was in error in asking the Government to settle the whole of Khasra No.61/1 on the respondent because whereas its area is 12.85 acres, the land companyered by the structures, including the appurtenant land, does number measure more than 2.85 acres. Mr. Purushottam Trikamdas, learned companynsel for the respondent readily companyceded this fact

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual area claimed and conceded is 2.85 acres, not entire khasra.

holdings.text: Precise area of land covered by structures and appurtenant thereto to be determined by revenue authorities in settlement proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with him. It would be sufficient to direct the Government to settle with the respondent the whole of the land companyered by the structures as well as land appurtenant to those structures from out of Khasra No. 61/1. What the area of that land would be is a matter to be determined during the settlement proceedings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Factual measurement and passages between structures require administrative determination.

anchor.surface_text: the decision in Moir v. Williams 1  In that case Lord Esher has observed that the term building generally means all 1 1892 1 Q.B. 217.

precedents.cited_proposition: the term building generally means all enclosures of brick and stone covered by a roof
precedents.cited_holding: the term building generally means all enclosures of brick and stone covered by a roof

precedents.citation: Morrison v. Commissioners of Inland Revenne 1915 1 K. B. 176

anchor.surface_text: He also relied upon the decision in Morrison v. Commissioners of Inland Revenne 1 . That was a case under the Finance 1909-10 Act, 1910 10 Miw. 7 c. 8 . The observations on which he relied are as follows It is quite clear that the expression buildings does

precedents.case_name: Morrison v Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: the expression buildings does not mean everything that can by any means be described as built it means buildings in a more narrow sense than structures
precedents.cited_holding: It is quite clear that the expression buildings does number mean everything that can by any means be described as built it means buildings in a more narrow sense than struct- ures

precedents.citation: Samuel Small v. Parkway Auto Supplies 49 A.I.R. 1361

anchor.surface_text: Finally he relied upon the decision in Samuel Small v. Parkway Auto Supplies 2 . The observations relied on by him are as follows The word building in its ordinary sense denotes a structure or edifice including a. space within its walls and usually companyered with a roof, such as a house, a church, a shop, a barn or a shed. The word building cannot be held to include every Species of erection on land, such as fences, gates or other like structures. Taken 1 1915 I K. B. 176 at 722. 2 49 A.I.R. 1361 at 1363.

precedents.case_name: Samuel Small v Parkway Auto Supplies
precedents.cited_proposition: word building in its ordinary sense denotes a structure or edifice including a space within its walls and usually covered with a roof and cannot include every erection on land such as fences gates
precedents.cited_holding: The word building in its ordinary sense denotes a structure or edifice including a. space within its walls and usually companyered with a roof, such as a house, a church, a shop, a barn or a shed. The word building cannot be held to include every Species of erection on land, such as fences, gates or other like structures.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Bindra pointed out that the High Court was in error in asking the Government to settle the whole of Khasra No.61/1 on the respondent because whereas its area is 12.85 acres, the land covered by the structures, including the appurtenant land, does number measure more than 2.85 acres. Mr. Purushottam Trikamdas, learned counsel for the respondent readily conceded this fact and said that the High Court has committed an error through an oversight and that all that the respondent wants is 2.85 acres of land and nothing more.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order modified to limit settlement to land covered by structures (ottas and chabutras) and appurtenant land (approx. 2.85 acres) out of Khasra No. 61/1 instead of entire area; area to be precisely determined by revenue authorities.
directions: Settle with the respondent the whole of the land covered by the structures as well as land appurtenant to those structures from out of Khasra No. 61/1
Precise area to be determined during the settlement proceedings

The doctrine of harmonious construction applied to s.4(1)(a) read with s.5(a), requiring settlement of land under proprietor's buildings including in bazar area, grounds the holding's broad interpretation of 'building' to include ottas and chabutras.

The harmonious construction of s.4(1)(a) and s.5(a) addresses the interpretive issue of what qualifies as 'buildings' by necessitating a construction that includes proprietor's structures in village sites like bazar areas, relevant to ottas and chabutras.

edges.explanation: The holding explicitly resolves the issue by determining that even uncovered ottas and chabutras constitute 'buildings' under s.5(a), necessitating their settlement with appurtenant land.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the High Court was quite right in holding that even uncovered ottas and chabutras fall within the term building as used in s. 5 a  of the Act and, therefore, along with the land appurtenant to them they must be settled with the respondent.

Mr. Purushottam Trikamdas, learned counsel for the respondent readily conceded this fact and said that the High Court has committed an error through an oversight and that all that the respondent wants is 2.85 acres of land and nothing more.

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 a  is an exception to s. 4 1  a  of the Act. No doubt, s. 4 1  a  provides for the vesting in the State of the land on which bazar is held. But reading that section along with s. 5 a  it is clear that where any buildings belonging to the proprietor exist on any portion of the abadi land that land, together with the land appurtenant to those buildings, bad to be settled with the ex-proprietor.
